Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 05:57AM redskyatnight wrote:  Sue and Maria, How soon did you go back to driving? I ventured out yesterday to the mall and between driving and trying on bras, I am sore- must've overdone it. I put a Wacoal soft cup sports bra on hold and then went to Macy's to check the selection. They carry the Warners Elements of Bliss no wire, but I couldn't find my size. I also ordered a "pretty bra" -Freya Pollyana in 34 D is it seems so highly recommended -and will just have to try it on when it arrives from the UK.  I know I sound a little crazy, but I definitley need the sports bra for vacation next week.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 08:08AM redskyatnight wrote: Sue, I, too am having my treatment done at a military hospital.  My fills have been done each time by a physician's assistant and she is doing a nice job- filling 50 ccs per side each week-no pain, just some pressure. Last week she only filled the BC side to catch it up with the prophy side. I do feel the needle on the prophy side. I have only seen my PS once during a follow up per my request at 3 weeks post-op. I wanted the PS to check out the incisions and make sure all was ok. I think he doesn't routinely check in unless there is a problem or request. My main concern is getting to the size that I will be happy with. My TE's are pretty small ( around 300ccs) as I have a small chest area, but my goal is to be a C with the implants (I was an A before bc, maybe up to a C when breastfeeding).  Maria, Sorry to hear about the aerobics class. Finding a closer location would be great, but I know you'll miss the regulars who attended you class. Maybe they'll move with you!  What kind of swimsuit ended up working for you? I will be looking for one as well to contain the TE's without feeling self-conscious! As far as exercising goes, I am happy to out be walking every day for 45 minutes or so. My kids are on spring break this week and they are walking the dog with me while I do my walks. Also, I am noticing that the exercises my PT gave me are really helping with the TE discomfort. Either that, or I am starting to heal up -I am 6 weeks post op. I see the PT tomorrow and want to find out how soon I can bike ride, and do more strenuous exercise such as classes at the gym etc... and what restrictions remain while healing and going through tissue expansion. It sounds like many of you are doing lots of exercise now. How far out were you cleared to do strenuous exercise? Tonight is our last meal delivery believe it or not! Now my husband and I are starting a more healthy and thoughtful eating plan-  we like to grill chicken, fish, and some red meat a lot in the warm months and also grill veggies and do lots of salads. We both want to reshape some after the whole ordeal our family has been through with my bc! I feel like my legs and abs need work and I need to drop some body fat. For the past 6 months since bc diagnosis we have been in kind of a tail spin. Now it's time to focus on getting back into shape. I'd love to feel fit and lean along with the timing of the final implants. It will be nice to look good for a 48 yr. old!  Rennasus, What a pretty pic! Love your red hair color! Annie- Awesome news of your LAST chemo day. That is just great!! Do something nice for yourself.  About the bras, I love the coobie bras - they are so comfortable and have removable pads. The pad helps cover the TE shape. The bra is one size fits all and is made of a soft, stretchy material. It has straps that can be removed or criss-crossed to adjust for clothing. I got mine at a local lingere shop. I googled to find who carries them locally. You can also order online.

We've had some nice spring weather lately here in MD, so the fresh air and sunshine feels great.   Got good results from my BS/tumor board today. No more cancer treatment is needed for me, just 6 month follow-ups w/my BS for exams. There was widespread dcis throughout the breast, so it was a good thing I had the MX. Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 01:55PM redskyatnight wrote: Barbara, I shoot for 3+ cardio workouts per week at a minimum and prefer getting 4-5 per week. It's been kinda shaky with these surgeries over the past year. Starting back, I'd suggest you try moderate intensity (where you can breathe comfortably) for let's say 15-30 minutes, or whatever you can comfortably do. Then, every week, increase your duration by 10%. So, for ex. 30 min-- 33 min. I try to target 40 minutes to an hour ideally for weight control. Then, you can begin playing around with intensity once you have a good fitness base. So do some hard/easy intervals (such as 5 min. warm-up, then 1 minute at 85% of max effort and 1-2 min. easy and repeat several times.Then do a 5 min. cool-down) on the bike/elliptical/swimming or whatever mode you are doing. The intervals will challenge your heart, lungs, and muscles and increase your fitness level  more rapidly. Right now my physical therapy exercises suffice for my strength training until my back is in good order. For strength 2-3 x week is good. This includes anything like weights, doing sit-ups/plank/dynabands etc... at home, to group strength classes, vinyasa yoga, pilates etc.. in my opinion! I record my workouts in a simple calendar book/daytimer that I use for my personal tracking such as dr. visits, menstrual cycle, aches and pains, illness, etc.. kind of a health-related journal. It is a motivational tool for me to be able to check off that I did my workout that day and x workouts/week and then look back at how I did. I also have done a food journal in the past-- again as a motivational tool for me because you just hate to write down food binges etc! Plus it is great for self-awareness (we often forget all of the little things we nibble on or drink) and making sure you get the targeted servings of vegs, fruits, grains, dairy, protein, etc...You can use apps like spark people and livestrong or whatever suits you. For me, simply jotting things down seems to help-I am "old-school" and prefer a paper daytimer to an electronic device.  Hope this helps!

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 09:22PM redskyatnight wrote: Hi All, Well, today was supposed to be my big day -surgery, but I was sent home after waiting for 6 hours in pre-op- fasting and all. I was running a fever -  99 when admitted, and then 100.2 after sitting with a bear paws heating system device blowing on me for several hours. When my BS heard that I had a fever,  he cancelled my surgery.  My BS said it is risky to undergo surgery with an infection-problems w/ TE's becoming infected etc. I want to go into this at 100% that's for sure.  Disappointed, but glad my doctor is looking out for me.   Had a full exam and labs  and everything looks healthy, so unsure if I am getting a virus?  Needless to say it was a long day .  I must be fever free for 48 hrs and then reschedule.Will keep you posted on the new date-hope it is sooner rather than later.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 12:21PM redskyatnight wrote: Hi All, Thanks for your wishes and prayers.  Tomorrow I go in for my BMX+TE's.  Good to hear everyone's reports-it sure helps to anticipate the in's and out's of this process. SuperSally and dmho I wish you both all the best tomorrow with your surgeries. I'll check back to report how things went for me afterwards. A Couple of tips I wanted to pass on from another BC survivor for post-op:  get a hair washing tray for use at the sink, and hair freshening powder in lieu of a hair wash. I am heading over to Bed Bath and Beyond for the tray and Sally Beauty Supply for the powder spray today. Apparently it may be a couple of weeks before you can shower and wash your hair normally.  She also recommended taking a warm bubble bath and have a loofah with a handle (for your spouse or friend to wash your back). She said it felt great and then you go from the bath to taking a nap! Take good care everyone!

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 01:47PM redskyatnight wrote: Barbara, I am with you! My surgery is in a week too and I am wondering how I will get through the week without being a nervous wreck. I have a list of things to do to be organized around the house and have my mother coming out from Dallas to help. Exercise has really helped to improve my state of mind and relieve stress. My husband has to field all of my concerns and worries-poor guy I've had too many words! I seem to come up with new worries every day from how I am going to react post-surgery when I see my chest with breasts gone, to how painful the TE's will be to tolerate, to my surgical pathology report... My daughter's 9th birthday falls right after surgery and I don't want her to feel forgotten; just lots of stuff. It will be a relief to have the surgery over and then to focus on the next step of treatment/recovery. Prayers and warm wishes to all of you.
